rev.diff:
Line 145: Line 145:
== Proprietary software ==
== Proprietary software ==
  +
''See also: [[List of proprietary software for Linux]]''
  +
Some specific proprietary software products are not available in any form for Linux. This includes many popular computer games, although in recent years [[Linux gaming#Commercial games|some game manufacturers]] have begun making their software available for Linux, such as [[Epic Games]]' ''[[Unreal Tournament 2004]]''. [[emulator|Emulation]] and API-translation projects like [[Wine (software)|Wine]] and [[Cedega]] make it possible to run non-Linux-based software on Linux systems, either by emulating a proprietary operating system or by translating proprietary API calls (e.g., calls to Microsoft's [[Win32]] or [[DirectX]] APIs) into native Linux API calls. A [[virtual machine]] can also be used to run a proprietary OS on top of Linux.
Some specific proprietary software products are not available in any form for Linux. This includes many popular computer games, although in recent years [[Linux gaming#Commercial games|some game manufacturers]] have begun making their software available for Linux, such as [[Epic Games]]' ''[[Unreal Tournament 2004]]''. [[emulator|Emulation]] and API-translation projects like [[Wine (software)|Wine]] and [[Cedega]] make it possible to run non-Linux-based software on Linux systems, either by emulating a proprietary operating system or by translating proprietary API calls (e.g., calls to Microsoft's [[Win32]] or [[DirectX]] APIs) into native Linux API calls. A [[virtual machine]] can also be used to run a proprietary OS on top of Linux.
